TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi sealed beforefieldinit WebEventBufferFlushInfo extends System.Object

Docs.summary: Contains the parameters defining the flush buffer characteristics.

remarks.format:
## Remarks ASP.NET health monitoring allows production and operations staff to manage deployed Web applications. The <xref:System.Web.Management> namespace contains the health-event types responsible for packaging application health-status data and the provider types responsible for processing this data. It also contains supporting types that help during the management of health events.
The WebEventBufferFlushInfo class defines values that identify the buffer's current status. An instance of the class is passed as a parameter to the <xref:System.Web.Management.BufferedWebEventProvider.ProcessEventFlush%2A> method that processes the messages that have been buffered. ASP.NET health monitoring calls this method when the flushing of the buffer is required. This is determined by the parameters defined by the `bufferModes` element in the `healthMonitoring` configuration section.
> [!NOTE] > By design, the buffering mechanism might drop some events in order to keep pace with the incoming events. It is up to the user to adjust this mechanism by properly modifying the `bufferModes` element in the `healthMonitoring` configuration section.
## Examples The following code example shows how to use the WebEventBufferFlushInfo class. This code example is part of a larger example provided for the <xref:System.Web.Management.BufferedWebEventProvider> class.
[!code-cs[System.Web.Management.BufferedWebEventProvider#6](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/t-system.web.management._21_1.cs)] [!code-vb[System.Web.Management.BufferedWebEventProvider#6](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/t-system.web.management._21_1.vb)]

Docs.summary: Gets the events collection in the current message.
Docs.value: The events contained in the current message.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Due to buffering, several events are usually sent in a single message.
## Examples The following code example shows how to use the Events property. This code example is part of a larger example provided for the <xref:System.Web.Management.BufferedWebEventProvider> class.
[!code-cs[System.Web.Management.BufferedWebEventProvider#11](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.web.management._37_1.cs)] [!code-vb[System.Web.Management.BufferedWebEventProvider#11](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.web.management._37_1.vb)]

Docs.summary: Gets the number of events dropped since the last notification.
Docs.value: The number of events dropped by the buffering mechanism since the last notification.

remarks.format:
## Remarks By design, the buffering mechanism might drop some events in order to keep pace with the incoming events. It is up to the user to adjust this mechanism by properly modifying the `bufferModes` element in the `healthMonitoring` configuration section.
## Examples The following code example shows how to use the EventsDiscardedSinceLastNotification property. This code example is part of a larger example provided for the <xref:System.Web.Management.BufferedWebEventProvider> class.
[!code-cs[System.Web.Management.BufferedWebEventProvider#12](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/ed0a9fe0-9d40-4ea5-b3f6-_1.cs)] [!code-vb[System.Web.Management.BufferedWebEventProvider#12](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/ed0a9fe0-9d40-4ea5-b3f6-_1.vb)]

Docs.summary: Gets the number of events in the buffer.
Docs.value: The number of events in the buffer.

remarks.format:
## Remarks This number is captured at the beginning of the notification.

Docs.summary: Gets the date and the time of the last notification.
Docs.value: The date and the time of the last notification.

remarks.format:

Docs.summary: Gets the message sequence in the current notification.
Docs.value: The number indicating the message sequence order in the current notification, beginning with an index of zero.

remarks.format:
